newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean stocks close down, Hansol firms recover.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean stocks close down, Hansol firms recover.

text.p: Seoul stocks closed lower on Thursday on jitters over corporate financial troubles sparked by a textile maker's debt default news, brokers said.
Blue chips fell as institutional investors took to the sidelines. Hansol Group affiliates recovered early losses that were a result of Wednesday's negative newspaper report.
The composite index ended down 0.64 percent, or 4.41 points, at 684.69 after ranging from 682.73 to 690.44.
Affiliates of the troubled Jinro Group sharply rose in an immediate rebound following Wednesday's sharp declines.
The Jinro Group, struggling under heavy debts, has put some of its property and affiliates on sale to raise cash.
"Bargain hunting set in as the index approached the 680 level that many investors saw as a strong support level," said Koh Soon-shik of LG Securities.
Brokers saw the market rebounding on Friday in response to a three-percent drop over the past four consecutive trading days.

Five of seven listed Hansol units ended flat after staying in negative territory for most of the day. The group was hit by news reports it had managed a seven billion won fund on behalf of an associate of President Kim Young-sam's son.
Hansol, the nation's 16th largest industrial conglomerate, has denied the reports.
"In terms of share prices of Hansol firms, the impact from the news seems to have been reflected enough," said Lim Chong-woo of Ssangyong Investment and Securities.
Ke Mong Sa Publishing rose 2,700 won to its limit of 36,600. A company official said it was negotiating with a Japanese electronics maker to import infrared consumer devices.
Hyundai Motor was unmoved by a spokesman's remarks that its chances had improved to win approval to build a joint venture plant in Vietnam.
Hyundai lost 100 won to close at 21,300. Hyundai, which is seeking a 65 percent stake in the venture, plans to build a plant with an annual capacity of 10,000 vehicles.
Textile maker Yu Sung Co filed for court receivership on Tuesday after defaulting on debt payments. Yu Sung's troubles rekindled concerns about other shaky companies.
Trading of Yu Sung shares was suspended through Thursday.
Brokers forecast stocks backed by rich assets, those that are targets of possible takeover bids and those with strong earnings growth potential would be in demand on Friday.
